DOC.HEAD: Guilty Plea of Marijuana Broker Caps Sting Operation
DOC.TEXT: A man prosecutors called the biggest single broker of Southeast Asian marijuana pleaded guilty to smuggling nearly 200 tons into the United States over a four-year period. Brian Peter Daniels, 43, appeared before U.S. District Judge John Coughenour on Tuesday to plead guilty to one count of operating a continuing criminal enterprise and two counts of conspiracy to import and distribute marijuana. Daniels, a New York native who had lived in Thailand for about 10 years until his 1988 arrest in Switzerland, could be sentenced to life in prison and fined up to $6.25 million. Sentencing was set for May 25. Daniels is being held without bail in the Pierce County Jail. Daniels admitted in court documents that he masterminded some of the biggest marijuana shipments from Southeast Asia to the United States from 1984 to 1988. The shipments included multiton deliveries to Seattle, southern California, Oregon, Nevada, British Columbia and Mexico. Among them was the shipment of 72 tons of high-grade Laotian marijuana seized in June 1988 aboard the Encounter Bay, an oil-supply vessel, off the Washington coast. ``As far as I'm aware he was the single biggest broker of Southeast Asian marijuana,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Peter Mueller. The guilty plea was part of an agreement in which some charges in Seattle, San Diego, and Reno, Nev., were packaged into a single plea agreement filed in Seattle. The guilty plea capped a ``sting'' operation by the federal Drug Enforcement Administration, in which DEA agents in Seattle, Reno, Miami, Hong Kong and Bangkok collaborated to ensnare Daniels. Dozens of other defendants have been prosecuted in Seattle, San Diego and Reno and arrest warrants have been issued for other key figures who are still fugitives. Swiss police and DEA agents arrested Daniels in July 1988 in Zurich, Switzerland, where he had gone for medical treatment.
